[[File:PSM V23 D302 William Farr.jpg|thumb|William Farr]]
'''William Farr''' (30 November 1807 – 14 April 1883) was a nineteenth-century British [[epidemiologist]], regarded as one of the founders of [[medical statistics]].

==Early life==
He was born in [[Kenley, Shropshire]], [[England]] to poor parents.  He was effectively adopted by a local squire, Joseph Pryce, when Farr and his family moved to [[Dorrington, Shropshire|Dorrington]]. In 1826 he took a job as a dresser (surgeon's assistant) in [[Shrewsbury, Shropshire|Shrewsbury]] infirmary. Pryce died in November 1828, and left Farr £500 ({{Inflation|UK|500|1828|r=-2|fmt=eq|cursign=£}}), which allowed him to study medicine in [[France]] and [[Switzerland]]. In Paris he heard [[Pierre Charles Alexandre Louis]] lecture.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ian Hacking|title=The Taming of Chance|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ud7EzIBwQBwC&pg=PA84|accessdate=21 June 2013|date=31 August 1990|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-38884-9|page=84}}</ref>

Farr returned to England in 1831 and continued his studies at [[University College London]], qualifying as a licentiate of the [[Society of Apothecaries]] in March 1832. He married in 1833 and started a medical practice in [[Fitzroy Square]], London.  He became involved in medical journalism and statistics.<ref name="ODNB"/>

==General Register Office==
[[File:William Farr 2.jpg|thumb|William Farr, about 1850]]
In 1837 the [[General Register Office for England and Wales|General Register Office]] (GRO) took on the responsibility for the [[United Kingdom Census 1841]]. Farr was hired there, initially on a temporary basis to handle data from [[vital registration]].<ref name="ODNB">{{cite ODNB|id=9185|title=Farr, William|first=John M.|last=Eyler}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=William G. Rothstein|title=Public Health and the Risk Factor: A History of an Uneven Medical Revolution|url=http://books.google.com/books?.id=rmwp7X2FZ68C&pg=PA29|accessdate=21 June 2013|year=2003|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|isbn=978-1-58046-127-6|page=29}}</ref> Then, with a recommendation from [[Edwin Chadwick]] and backing from [[Neil Arnott]], Farr secured another post in the GRO as the first compiler of scientific abstracts (i.e. a statistician).<ref>{{cite book|author=Dorothy Porter|title=Health, Civilization, and the State: A History of Public Health from Ancient to Modern Times|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=XswTsHJbQf8C&pg=PA70|accessdate=21 June 2013|year=1999|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-20036-3|page=70}}</ref><ref>{{cite ODNB|id=694|title=Arnott, Neil|first=Bill|last=Luckin}}</ref> Chadwick and Farr had an agenda, demography aimed at [[public health]], and the support of the initial Registrar General [[Thomas Henry Lister]]. Lister with Farr worked on the census design, to forward the programme.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Raymond Flood|author2=Adrian Rice|author3=Robin Wilson|title=Mathematics in Victorian Britain|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=QmzfJUShGYUC&pg=PA269|accessdate=21 June 2013|date=29 September 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-960139-4|page=269}}</ref>

Farr was responsible for the collection of official medical statistics in England and Wales.  His most important contribution was to set up a system for routinely recording the causes of death.  For example, for the first time it allowed the [[mortality rate]]s of different occupations to be compared.

==Learned societies and associations==
In 1839, Farr joined the [[Royal Statistical Society|Statistical Society]], in which he played an active part as treasurer, vice-president and president over the years. In 1855 he was elected [[Fellow of the Royal Society]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Norman L. Johnson|author2=Samuel Kotz|title=Leading Personalities in Statistical Sciences: From the Seventeenth Century to the Present|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=AzZZ-uW6WuEC&pg=PA286|accessdate=22 June 2013|date=26 September 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-15072-6|pages=286}}</ref> He was involved in the [[National Association for the Promotion of Social Science|Social Science Association]] from its foundation in 1857,<ref>{{cite book|author=Lawrence Goldman|title=Science, Reform, and Politics in Victorian Britain|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=io2nB6RcaIwC&pg=PA174|accessdate=22 June 2013|year=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-43301-3|page=174}}</ref> taking part in its Quarantine Committee and Committee on Trades' Societies and Strikes.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Michael J. Lacey|author2=Mary O. Furner|title=The State and Social Investigation in Britain and the United States|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=xOKwKZNzbQ0C&pg=PA107|accessdate=22 June 2013|date=25 June 1993|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-41638-2|page=107}}</ref>

==Research on cholera==
There was a major outbreak of [[cholera]] in London in 1849 which killed around 15,000 people.  Early industrialisation had made London the most populous city in the world at the time, and the [[River Thames]] was heavily polluted with untreated sewage. Farr subscribed to the conventional theory that cholera was carried by polluted air rather than water – the  [[miasma theory of disease|miasmic theory]]. On the other hand, as a result of studying this outbreak, the physician [[John Snow (physician)|John Snow]] proposed what is now the accepted mechanism for transmission: people were infected by swallowing something and it multiplied in the [[intestine]]s.

There was another epidemic in 1853, and Farr gathered statistical evidence. John Snow discovered that people supplied with water from two companies in particular: the Southwark & Vauxhall and the Lambeth water companies – which drew their water directly from the Thames were particularly likely to suffer.<ref>Aschengrau, A. & Seage, G. R. (2008). Essentials of epidemiology in public health. Pg:15-21 Sudbury, Mass.: Jones And Bartlett Publishers.</ref> Farr took part in the [[General Board of Health]]'s 1854 Committee for Scientific Enquiries. The conventional explanation for cholera was still [[contingent contagionism|multifactorial]]; Snow's view of cholera as solely caused by a [[pathogen]] was not accepted, though his evidence was taken seriously. Farr's research was detailed and showed an inverse correlation of mortality and elevation.<ref>{{cite book|author=Alfredo Morabia|title=A History of Epidemiologic Methods and Concepts|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=E-OZbEmPSTkC&pg=PA133|accessdate=22 June 2013|date=1 January 2004|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-7643-6818-0|pages=133–4}}</ref>

There was a further epidemic in 1866, by which time Snow had died, and Farr had accepted Snow's explanation. He produced a monograph which showed that mortality was extremely high for people who drew their water from the Old Ford Reservoir in East London. Farr's work was then considered conclusive.

==Later life==
In 1858, he performed a study on the correlation of health and marriage condition, and found that health decreases from the married to the unmarried to the widowed.<ref>Tara Parker-Pope (2010-04-14). [http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/18/magazine/18marriage-t.html Is Marriage Good for Your Health?] New York Times</ref> In the period 1857–9 the Office ordered a [[difference engine]], a model designed by Swedish followers of [[Charles Babbage]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Michael Lindgren|title=Glory and Failure: The Difference Engines of Johann Müller, Charles Babbage and Georg and Edvard Scheutz|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=plgMl2yfVkwC&pg=PA289|accessdate=21 June 2013|year=1990|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0-262-12146-0|page=289}}</ref> The intended application was the "British Life Table".<ref>{{cite book|author=Jeremy M. Norman|title=From Gutenberg to the Internet: A Sourcebook on the History of Information Technology|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=emmitTbOoFgC&pg=PA134|accessdate=21 June 2013|date=1 January 2005|publisher=Norman Publishing|isbn=978-0-930405-87-8|page=134}}</ref>
[[File:William Farr.jpg|thumb|left|William Farr, about 1870]]

Farr served as a commissioner in the 1871 census, retiring from the General Register Office in 1879 after he was not given the post of [[Registrar General]]. He received the Gold Medal of the [[BMA|British Medical Association]] for his work in the field of [[biostatistics]] and was made a [[British honours system|Companion of the Order of Bath]] in 1880.

In his last years, Farr's approach was obsolescent. [[Bacteriology]] had changed the face of the medical issues, and statistics became an increasingly mathematic tool. Medical reformers, too, changed approach, expecting less from legislation and central government.<ref>{{cite book|author=Lawrence Goldman|title=Science, Reform, and Politics in Victorian Britain|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=io2nB6RcaIwC&pg=PA200|accessdate=23 June 2013|year=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-43301-3|page=200}}</ref>

==Works==
In 1837 Farr wrote the chapter "Vital Statistics" for [[John Ramsey McCulloch]]'s ''Statistical Account of the British Empire''. In January  1837 he established the ''[[British Annals of Medicine, Pharmacy, Vital Statistics, and General Science]]'', discontinued in August of that year. He revised a book of [[James Fernandez Clarke]] on [[tuberculosis]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Norman L. Johnson|author2=Samuel Kotz|title=Leading Personalities in Statistical Sciences: From the Seventeenth Century to the Present|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=AzZZ-uW6WuEC&pg=PA284|accessdate=22 June 2013|date=26 September 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-15072-6|pages=284}}</ref>

Farr exploited his GRO post compiling abstracts in a way that went beyond the original job description. In so doing he applied the techniques of [[Benjamin Gompertz]] (the [[Gompertz curve]]), and the closely allied statistical "law of mortality" of [[Thomas Rowe Edmonds]]. Farr, by relying on the existing mathematical model of mortality, could use [[data sampling]] to cut back the required computation.<ref>{{cite book|author=Alfredo Morabia|title=A History of Epidemiologic Methods and Concepts|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=E-OZbEmPSTkC&pg=PA155|accessdate=21 June 2013|date=1 January 2004|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-7643-6818-0|page=155}}</ref> From the GRO data he constructed a series of national [[life tables]].<ref name="Stone1997">{{cite book|author=Richard Stone|title=Some British Empiricists in the Social Sciences, 1650-1900|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ccQFbSfF7PIC&pg=PA263|accessdate=21 June 2013|year=1997|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-57145-6|page=263}}</ref>

The theory of [[zymotic disease]] was Farr's contribution to the debate on [[aetiology]]. He identified urbanisation and [[population density]] as public health issues.<ref>{{cite book|author=Thomas Edward Jordan|title=The Degeneracy Crisis and Victorian Youth|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=LLNxB-a3n3YC&pg=PA218|accessdate=23 June 2013|year=1993|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-1-4384-0804-0|pages=217–8}}</ref> In terms of [[nosology]] he classed epidemic, endemic and contagious diseases as "zymotic", seen as diseases of filth and overcrowding.<ref>{{cite book|author=John M. Eyler|title=Sir Arthur Newsholme and State Medicine, 1885-1935|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9vOcq_BX25YC&pg=PA34|accessdate=23 June 2013|date=15 August 2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-52458-2|page=34}}</ref>

==In drama==
In ''[[Seven Wonders of the Industrial World#The Sewer King|The Sewer King]]'', an episode in the 2003 British television documentary series ''[[Seven Wonders of the Industrial World]]'', Farr was played by [[Norman Lovett]].<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0698582/ ''Seven Wonders of the Industrial World'' 'The Sewer King' (2003)]. [[Internet Movie Database]]</ref>

==Family==
Farr's first wife, whom he married in 1833, had the surname Langford; she died of [[tuberculosis]] in 1837. He married Mary Elizabeth Whittal in 1842, and they had eight children.<ref name="ODNB"/> One daughter, Henrietta, was married to painter and illustrator [[Henry Marriott Paget]], the older brother of illustrators [[Sidney Paget|Sidney]] and [[Walter Paget]]. Another daughter, [[Florence Farr]], was also a painter and artist and a model of many famous [[art deco]] works of art. The Pagets as well as the Farr sisters lived and worked in [[Bedford Park, London|Bedford Park]], the famous artist's colony in West London.
